alert.note: Alert for Lamoille (Vermont) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Burlington (Northern Vermont and New York)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued July 11 at 12:17PM EDT until July 12 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Burlington
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Vermont... Lamoille River At Johnson affecting Lamoille County. For the Lamoille River...including East Georgia, Johnson, Jeffersonville...Major flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL JUST AFTER MIDNIGHT TONIGHT... * WHAT...Major flooding is occurring. * WHERE...Lamoille River at Johnson. * WHEN...Until just after midnight tonight. * IMPACTS...Extensive flooding will continue from Hardwick downstream through Morrisville, Johnson, Jeffersonville and Cambridge until the river level falls below 16 feet. Specifically, Route 15 along the Lamoille from Morrisville to Cambridge, and the shopping center on lower Main Street in Johnson will flood, and homes and businesses along the Lamoille River will also likely flood. Below 16 feet, serious flooding will continue to be seen in Jeffersonville and Cambridge until the river level falls below 14 feet, where thereafter mainly field flooding will remain until the river is below 13 feet. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:30 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 19.6 feet. - Bankfull stage is 13.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:30 AM EDT Tuesday was 21.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late this evening and continue falling to 6.4 feet Friday morning. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - Flood History...The observed maximum river stage of 21 feet is the 2nd highest crest in history. This is higher than what was observed during Tropical Storm Irene where the stage reached 14.54 feet on 8/29/2011, but still well shy of the 1927 flood which reached 27 feet on 11/04/1927. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued late tonight at 200 AM EDT.
